text: <@U04HQD29Z7E> has joined the channel

Over the weekend I implemented `Matter` in `cesride` at parity with `KERIpy` (I believe). Here's the code:
<https://github.com/jasoncolburne/cesride/tree/spike>

It can probably use some more work, I'm a fairly new Rust coder (2 months but pretty intensive) but it's a good start. <@U024KC347B4> you probably want to check this out as I noticed you made some changes, too. I can open a PR for review if people want? I'm willing to contribute a great deal to this suite of projects in Rust.

I tested this by instantiating `Matter` several different ways, in one gross function. It grew out of what was there, I just kind of took the path of least resistance but this is where my work could benefit the most, I believe. Better tests. I will add them later. I did generate lots of tests for `Sizages` and `Codes` though. Normally I wouldn't throw down a 1300 line PR but this is a foundational bit that was hard to get away from.

For the curious, I used string transformations in Ruby to turn Python codexes etc into Rust code directly.

attachments.text:
*Rationale*

`Diger` is built upon `Matter` and hashing algorithms alone. It was a pretty simple next step after implementing `Matter`.

*Testing*

The code was so simple I merely exhausted the primary control flows. The digest tests ensure we don't mismatch an algorithm, they aren't intended to test the hasing functions themselves.

I added a test for 'compare' ported from KERIpy, as it exercises more code than the other tests.

*Notes*

With 512-bit digests, ahead of KERIpy.

Currently we have a sprinkling of `.into()`, `to_owned()` and `to_string()`

The operations are equivalent in terms of performance, we've decided to align on `to_string()`

For reference:  
<https://users.rust-lang.org/t/current-guidance-on-str-to-string-to-owned-vs-to-string/75754/2|https://users.rust-lang.org/t/current-guidance-on-str-to-string-to-owned-vs-to-string/75754/2>

attachments.text: Noticed that we weren't validating the code upon all avenues of creation for Diger. Parity with python involves catching these cases in the `qb64()`, `qb64b()` and `qb2()` parsing functions. To top it all off, we weren't checking this during `new_with_code_and_raw()`, either. This should make things much safer.

attachments.text:
*Rationale*

Was going to implement `Cigar` but it depended on `Verfer`. `Verfer` only needed signature verification.

*Changes*

• added `Verfer` core functionality
• added `ed25519` support for `Verfer`
• added `secp256k1` support for `Verfer`

*Testing*

Tests surpass those performed in KERIpy, which are quite minimal.

*Notes*

It appears KERIpy was doing verifications with hashing, rather than verifying a pre-hashed digest. Without going back to the paper, I do not know if this is correct. I did what looked to be the same, which I think means that `ser` typically need not be capped at the point size of the curve. Unsure if this is intentional.

I also tried integrating the `ed448-goldilocks` but it's a pure math package, it doesn't contain signing/serialization wrappers. I could figure out how to implement this and have done similar things in the past but it's probably involved and out of scope here. If I do this in the future I'll pull it in.

attachments.text:
Our errors are getting out of hand and we need to do something to reduce the number of variants. Many can be grouped and details specified at runtime. As an example, we could turn this:

```
    #[error("unexpected code error: {0}")]
    UnexpectedCode(String),
    #[error("unexpected count code error: {0}")]
    UnexpectedCountCode(String),
    #[error("unexpected op code error: {0}")]
    UnexpectedOpCode(String),
```

into

```
    #[error("unexpected code error: {0}")]
    UnexpectedCode(String),
```

And simply specify the op and count information in the supplied string.
attachments.title: <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/cesride/issues/51|#51 Consolidate and Minimize Errors>

attachments.text:
*Rationale*

Constants were gross, like this:

```
const SIXTY_FOUR: u32 = 64;
if count > SIXTY_FOUR.pow(<http://szg.ss|szg.ss>) - 1 {
// ...
```

This PR changes integral constants to the standard approach, `1_u32` for `1` as a `u32` for example. In the case of the example above, we'd end up with `if count > 64_u32.pow(<http://szg.ss|szg.ss>) - 1`.

*Changes*

Fixes constants as above, and moves remaining constants into `<http://tables.rs|tables.rs>` as that seemed a more appropriate place for module specific constants.

*Testing*

Standard test suite covers these changes.
attachments.title: <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/cesride/pull/57|#57 fix constants>

attachments.text:
*Rationale*

This cleans up the boxing of errors, which I've always hated. Instead of this:

```
return Err(Box::new(Error::SomeError()));
```

we now have

```
return err!(Error::SomeError());
```

*Changes*

As described above.

Also had to reduce patch coverage target since many errors are unreachable, thus changes like this that affect all errors impact patch coverage. More importantly, though, project coverage is barely changing (no tangible difference) and that target is still 95%.

*Testing*

Explicit unit tests exercise the macro.

we now have

return err!(Error::SomeError());

*Changes*

attachments.text:
*Rationale*

Constants were gross, like this:

```
const SIXTY_FOUR: u32 = 64;
if count > SIXTY_FOUR.pow(<http://szg.ss|szg.ss>) - 1 {
// ...
```

This PR changes integral constants to the standard approach, `1_u32` for `1` as a `u32` for example. In the case of the example above, we'd end up with `if count > 64_u32.pow(<http://szg.ss|szg.ss>) - 1`.

*Changes*

Fixes constants as above, and moves remaining constants into `<http://tables.rs|tables.rs>` as that seemed a more appropriate place for module specific constants.

*Testing*

Standard test suite covers these changes.

attachments.text:
*Rationale*

Wanted to set us up for success. I created the beginnings of the Rust API layer and the Python FFI. Comments welcome.

Also, this unlocks parallel streams of work and tasks with a lower bar to entry for the project.

*Changes*

• Exposes Rust API and maintains standard crate configuration.
• Creates Python API with a simple `Matter` class exposed.
• Adds a Makefile and some targets for easier scripting (abusing make a bit but it's available everywhere)
• Updates `README.md` with instructions for new developers.

I am pretty happy with how I cleaned up the directory structure after a few iterations and separated the python code from the main library. The only changes to the core library are to support a simple `#[pyclass]` above the definition of the struct.

*Testing*

You are encouraged to check out the branch and try these commands.

```
> make clean libs preflight python-shell
Python 3.10.6 (main, Aug 11 2022, 13:49:25) [Clang 13.1.6 (clang-1316.0.21.2.5)] on darwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> from cesride import Matter
>>> m = Matter(qb64="BGlOiUdp5sMmfotHfCWQKEzWR91C72AH0lT84c0um-Qj")
>>> qb2 = m.qb2()
>>> print(qb2)
[4, 105, 78, 137, 71, 105, 230, 195, 38, 126, 139, 71, 124, 37, 144, 40, 76, 214, 71, 221, 66, 239, 96, 7, 210, 84, 252, 225, 205, 46, 155, 228, 35]
>>> m2 = Matter(qb2=bytes(qb2))
>>> m2.qb64()
'BGlOiUdp5sMmfotHfCWQKEzWR91C72AH0lT84c0um-Qj'
>>> m3 = Matter(code=m.code(), raw=bytes(m.raw()), raw_size=len(m.raw()))
>>> m3.qb64()
'BGlOiUdp5sMmfotHfCWQKEzWR91C72AH0lT84c0um-Qj'
>>> Matter(qb64="_" * 44)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
Exception: unexpected code error: op code start
>>> Matter(qb64="-" * 44)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
Exception: unexpected code error: count code start
```

attachments.text:
*Rationale*

As a library we don't really want pinned dependencies, but we do want to avoid breakage. <https://semver.org|Semantic versioning> allows us to pin the `major` version and be confident that `minor` and `patch` changes won't break functionality.

Caveat: versions with `major` = `0` may disobey these rules, thus I have pinned them to the first non-zero value in the sequence `[major, minor, patch]`.

*Changes*

• Uses `~` to lock dependency `major` (or `minor` if `major` = `0`) versions.
• Unpins dev dependencies entirely.

*Testing*

`make clean fix preflight python python-shell`

attachments.text:
*Rationale*

As a library we don't really want pinned dependencies, but we do want to avoid breakage. <https://semver.org|Semantic versioning> allows us to pin the `major` version and be confident that `minor` and `patch` changes won't break functionality.

Caveat: versions with `major` = `0` may disobey these rules, thus I have pinned them to the first non-zero value in the sequence `[major, minor, patch]`.

*Changes*

• Uses `~` to lock dependency `major` (or `minor` if `major` = `0`) versions.
• Unpins dev dependencies entirely.

*Testing*

`make clean fix preflight python python-shell`

We have the option to clean up our test code by using a crate called `rstest`. This will allow us to do things like select sets of parameters and expected results to test over, executing common code many times, rather than having long sequences of the same code or multiple test functions doing essentially the same thing.

<https://docs.rs/rstest/latest/rstest/#creating-parametrized-tests|https://docs.rs/rstest/latest/rstest/#creating-parametrized-tests>  
<https://docs.rs/rstest/latest/rstest/#creating-a-test-for-each-combinations-of-given-values|https://docs.rs/rstest/latest/rstest/#creating-a-test-for-each-combinations-of-given-values>  
<https://docs.rs/rstest/latest/rstest/#magic-conversion|https://docs.rs/rstest/latest/rstest/#magic-conversion>

*Rationale*

I started this after the primary contributers discussed in <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/cesride/issues/70|#70> - and it really cleans things up. In my opinion, the modified tests are far easier to scan and reason about.

*Changes*

• creates parameterized inputs for tests using `rstest`, where appropriate
• standardizes on using the full path for test imports, which would allow us to more easily copy/paste them somewhere else if need be

*Notes*

• I didn't look at `Indexer` as <https://github.com/m00sey|@m00sey> is working on that and didn't want to create conflicts. If this gets merged I'll create yet another issue to track the `Indexer` `rstest` status.
• I took a look at the diff and this one came out a bit confusing. Play with the presentation settings for an easier review.

text:
Hey,
Why do we have `Matter` as `structure` and `Verfer`, `Diger`, etc as `traits`?
What’s idea behind this?

As for me it should be opposite. if we want to define different kinds of primitives there should be defined  `Matter` as `trait` and add structures `Verfer` , `Diger` , etc which implements `Matter`,
Groups will consists of various primitives.

With currently implemented approach, if I have `Matter` instance I can call any methods from all implemented traits `Verfer` `Diger` etc .  That seems to be wrong.
Using `trait` as a fields of `Group` structure adds a lot of complexity because we have to wrap it into `Box` .

text:
It was the idea behind moving quickly and people learning Rust as they went, with a focus on porting as much logic as we could while we had resources available to bootstrap a project that had been idle for six months.

Glad you're here now though.

Correct Matter is essentially an abstract class not something you would initialize directly, the others are.

attachments.text:
<https://github.com/Artemkaaas|@Artemkaaas> commented the following:

```
Hey,
Why do we have Matter as structure and Verfer, Diger, etc as traits?
What’s idea behind this?
As for me it should be opposite. if we want to define different kinds of primitives there should be defined  Matter as trait and add structures Verfer , Diger , etc which implements Matter,
Groups will consists of various primitives.
With currently implemented approach, if I have Matter instance I can call any methods from all implemented traits Verfer Diger etc .  That seems to be wrong.
Using trait as a fields of Group structure adds a lot of complexity because we have to wrap it into Box .
```

The observation is correct, <https://github.com/jasoncolburne|@jasoncolburne> and myself missed adhering to the premise Matter is essentially an abstract concept, providing behavior (infil/exfil/binfil/besfil) to derivatives.

<https://github.com/jasoncolburne|@jasoncolburne> implemented `Cigar` as a struct composing Matter to access its behavior.

I think this is a good first refactor for the remaining `Diger` and `Verfer` implementations.

A second refactor would be to move Matter to a trait. Separate issue <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/cesride/issues/73|#73>
attachments.title: <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/cesride/issues/72|#72 Implement Vefer and Diger as Structs.>

attachments.text:
As commented in <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/cesride/issues/72|#72>

Matter would be better used abstractly.

Currently the matter implementation uses member variables for code/raw etc and mutates them internally.

We should add `get_code()` `get_raw()` to a Matter Trait and move the member variables up to Diger/Cigar/Verfer.

A Matter Trait could look something like:

```
pub trait Matter {
pub fn qb64b(&self) -> Result<Vec<u8>> //with default impl
pub fn qb2(&self) -> Result<Vec<u8>> //with default impl
pub fn code(&self) -> String
pub fn raw(&self) -> Vec<u8>

fn infil(&self) -> Result<String> //with default impl
fn binfil(&self) -> Result<Vec<u8>> //with default impl
fn exfil(&mut self, qb64: &str) -> Result<()> //with default impl
fn bexfil(&mut self, qb2: &[u8]) -> Result<()> //with default impl
}
```
attachments.title: <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/cesride/issues/73|#73 Refactor Matter to be a Trait.>

elements.text: for visibility, working on the Matter refactor:

attachments.text:
*Rationale*

We want to reverse trait modelling to turn `Matter` into an abstract 'class'. Read <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/cesride/issues/72|#72> and <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/cesride/issues/73|#73> for more details.

*Changes*

These:

```
<Matter as Verfer>::new_with_code_and_raw()
```

become

```
Verfer::new_with_code_and_raw()
```

Aso had to wrap up setters and getters for these concrete 'classes' so `Matter` code can interact with them.

Though we will probably move to `uniffi` soon, I also modified the python bindings for `Matter` to now expose `Diger`. It would be simple to add the other 'classes', but `uniffi` was very nice to me when I tried it out on another complex library.

*Testing*

`make clean preflight python python-shell`

A second refactor would be to move Matter to a trait. Separate issue <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/cesride/issues/73|#73>

attachments.text:
*Rationale*

We want to reverse trait modelling to turn `Matter` into an abstract 'class'. Read <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/cesride/issues/72|#72> and <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/cesride/issues/73|#73> for more details.

*Changes*

These:

```
<Matter as Verfer>::new_with_code_and_raw()
```

become

```
Verfer::new_with_code_and_raw()
```

Aso had to wrap up setters and getters for these concrete 'classes' so `Matter` code can interact with them.

Though we will probably move to `uniffi` soon, I also modified the python bindings for `Matter` to now expose `Diger`. It would be simple to add the other 'classes', but `uniffi` was very nice to me when I tried it out on another complex library.

*Testing*

`make clean preflight python python-shell`
attachments.title: <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/cesride/pull/75|#75 refactor `Matter` into trait>

attachments.text:
As commented in <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/cesride/issues/72|#72>

Matter would be better used abstractly.

Currently the matter implementation uses member variables for code/raw etc and mutates them internally.

We should add `get_code()` `get_raw()` to a Matter Trait and move the member variables up to Diger/Cigar/Verfer.

A Matter Trait could look something like:

```
pub trait Matter {
pub fn qb64b(&self) -> Result<Vec<u8>> //with default impl
pub fn qb2(&self) -> Result<Vec<u8>> //with default impl
pub fn code(&self) -> String
pub fn raw(&self) -> Vec<u8>

fn infil(&self) -> Result<String> //with default impl
fn binfil(&self) -> Result<Vec<u8>> //with default impl
fn exfil(&mut self, qb64: &str) -> Result<()> //with default impl
fn bexfil(&mut self, qb2: &[u8]) -> Result<()> //with default impl
}
```

> If you've modified the python code, either add some python tests (you'll need to do that yourself, none have been added) or run this code (and additionally exercising the changes you made):

make python python-shell

# in python shell
from cesride import Matter
m = Matter(qb64="BGlOiUdp5sMmfotHfCWQKEzWR91C72AH0lT84c0um-Qj")
qb2 = m.qb2()
print(qb2)
m2 = Matter(qb2=bytes(qb2))
m2.qb64()
```

is incorrect. See a comment below for reasoning on removing this section.

We should establish a contributing section as well, so that it is clearer how to being development.

attachments.text:
We currently have 2 implementations for the `bard` functionality (binary hard part of a code) and we're working on a third. We should establish a consistent pattern. Thanks to <https://github.com/m00sey|@m00sey> for pointing this out.

• option 1 (<https://github.com/m00sey|@m00sey>'s proposal for `Indexer`) - use binary strings and a HashMap (?): `b'\x00': 1, b'\x04': 1, b'\x08': 1, b'\x0c': 1, b'\x10': 1, b'\x14': 1`
• <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/cesride/blob/main/src/core/counter/tables.rs#L42-L61|option 2> - use decimal values and a match statement
• <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/cesride/blob/main/src/core/matter/mod.rs#L382-L403|option 3> - convert to a hard on the fly

Further optimizations

• pull something like a hex crate in to define the values more cleanly
• make a hex macro that does this for internal use

attachments.text:
*Rationale*

This cleans up the Codexes and may allow us to bypass the FFI problem we were having with `uniffi`. In general it seems like a really good change, thanks to Joseph for suggesting it in a CESR meeting.

*Changes*

In general, this changes code like this:

```
Codex::SomeVariant.code()
```

to this:

```
Codex::SomeVariant
```

• converts `Codex` enums to modules, making the variants constants.
• `has_code()` was easy to modify to be a function in the module, the consuming code didn't change

*Testing*

```
make clean preflight
```

Right now to initialize the trait based 'classes' that are mimicking the python architecture, we need to do this:

```
<Matter as Diger>::new_with_code_and_ser(matter::Codex::Blake3_256.code(), ser);
```

Investigate aliasing so we can simply write `Diger::new_with_code_and_ser(/* ... */)`.

attachments.text:
*Rationale*

This is one of the most critical pieces of the KERI space in general. Saidifying data is really the guts of what CESR is all about.

*Changes*

• implements `Saider`
• implements `Value` data object and `data!()` macro - these allow us to construct arbitrarily shaped data more easily
• moves crypto to crypto modules `hash` and `sign`
• creates `common` module for common things like `versify()`...
• cleans up code
• uses `Option<>` quite a bit, and this is new for us. I'm thinking to make a ticket and go back to the existing code to do the same, now that I've figured out a few good patterns
• renames test modules to `test` and removes `test_` prefix from functions to eliminate redundancy
• executes `cargo fmt` earlier in CI to save credits
• bumps checkout action version

*Testing*

Ported the meat of the KERIpy tests.

```
make clean preflight
```

attachments.text:
*Rationale*

This PR adds `new()` methods with optional parameters to all the primitives, bringing us closer to `KERIpy`.

*Changes*

• cleanup after <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/cesride/pull/91|#91>
• adds `new()` methods, allowing for `strip` param
• refactors all tests to use `new()`/public methods
• removes unnecessary creation methods
• evaluates and updates scoping of exposed structs, traits and functions
• adds some more rstest things

*Testing*

I tested all the paths in these new functions. My largest concern is that I may be incorrectly assigning or not assigning a default somewhere. I was quite careful though, I thought through all the use cases.

```
make clean preflight
```

*Notes*

`Counter` remains a bit of a mess. I'm making another ticket, but essentially it is called an abstract class but I do not see its use in `coring.py`.. So it should probably be a trait, but it's not.

attachments.text:
*Rationale*

Prefixer is the next step on the path to enabling real world use cases.

*Changes*

• implements `Prefixer`
• renames `*_sad_paths()` to `*_unhappy_paths()` to avoid confusion with the concept of a SAD.
• changes `lazy_static!` to `const` where we can
• fixes `strip` implementation
• supports:

```
// non-transferable
matter::Codex::Ed25519N,
matter::Codex::ECDSA_256k1N,

// transferable
matter::Codex::Ed25519,
matter::Codex::ECDSA_256k1,

// digests
matter::Codex::Blake3_256,
matter::Codex::Blake3_512,
matter::Codex::Blake2b_256,
matter::Codex::Blake2b_512,
matter::Codex::Blake2s_256,
matter::Codex::SHA3_256,
matter::Codex::SHA3_512,
matter::Codex::SHA2_256,
matter::Codex::SHA2_512,
```

*Testing*

Ported most everything from KERIpy and then added more to cover.

```
make clean fix preflight
```

Back when `Codexes` were `enums`, we needed to instantiate a `Vec` using `lazy_static!` to construct our validation checks. Now that `Codexes` are constants, this is not required and we can use a `const &[u8]`.

Example:

```
lazy_static! {
    static ref CODES: Vec<&'static str> = vec![
        matter::Codex::Blake3_256,
        matter::Codex::Blake3_512,
        matter::Codex::Blake2b_256,
        matter::Codex::Blake2b_512,
        matter::Codex::Blake2s_256,
        matter::Codex::SHA3_256,
        matter::Codex::SHA3_512,
        matter::Codex::SHA2_256,
        matter::Codex::SHA2_512,
    ];
}
```

becomes:

```
const CODES: &[&str] = &[
    matter::Codex::Blake3_256,
    matter::Codex::Blake3_512,
    matter::Codex::Blake2b_256,
    matter::Codex::Blake2b_512,
    matter::Codex::Blake2s_256,
    matter::Codex::SHA3_256,
    matter::Codex::SHA3_512,
    matter::Codex::SHA2_256,
    matter::Codex::SHA2_512,
];
```

I don't believe further changes are required.

Seqner is subclass of Matter, cryptographic material, for ordinal numbers such as sequence numbers or first seen ordering numbers.

Seqner provides fully qualified format for ordinals (sequence numbers etc) when provided as attached cryptographic material elements.

Useful when parsing attached receipt groupings with sn from stream or database.

Requires <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/cesride/issues/8|#8>

*Rationale*

Prefixer is the next step on the path to enabling real world use cases.

*Changes*

• implements `Prefixer`
• renames `*_sad_paths()` to `*_unhappy_paths()` to avoid confusion with the concept of a SAD.
• changes `lazy_static!` to `const` where we can
• fixes `strip` implementation
• supports:

```
// non-transferable
matter::Codex::Ed25519N,
matter::Codex::ECDSA_256k1N,

// transferable
matter::Codex::Ed25519,
matter::Codex::ECDSA_256k1,

// digests
matter::Codex::Blake3_256,
matter::Codex::Blake3_512,
matter::Codex::Blake2b_256,
matter::Codex::Blake2b_512,
matter::Codex::Blake2s_256,
matter::Codex::SHA3_256,
matter::Codex::SHA3_512,
matter::Codex::SHA2_256,
matter::Codex::SHA2_512,
```

*Testing*

Ported most everything from KERIpy and then added more to cover.

```
make clean fix preflight
```

attachments.text:
*Rationale*

This PR adds the convenience methods back by inverting the old pattern. Instead of the generic `new()` method depending on explicit creation methods with repeated custom logic, instead the generic new method pulls this custom logic in and the convenience methods wrap it.

This PR also makes some tweaks to the API after discussion and thought around where certain functionality should live within the package ecosystem. Parside is a better place for stream stripping, so we'll implement there. The `&mut Vec<u8>` inputs then change to simple `&[u8]`s.

*Changes*

• adds back convenience methods
• removes strip functionality

*Testing*

I actually managed to use regexes to replace everything and nothing broke!

```
make fix clean preflight
```

attachments.text:
*TL;DR*: Our dependencies should be audited to ensure they verify signatures in constant time.

Some paths are more sensitive that others with respect to constant time evaluation, but it's often the application that determines when this is required. In particular, we want to avoid verifications (and potentially other operations) that allow the adversary to glean knowledge about a particular operation due to differing response times. <https://cryptopals.com/sets/4/challenges/31|This> is a cryptopals exercise with an example of such an attack.

Basically, exiting algorithms and loops early may allow an attacker to understand how to forge signatures or otherwise defeat a cryptosystem. Constant time comparisons and algorithms combat these attacks.

We should evaluate our signing library dependencies to ensure they employ constant time algorithms.
attachments.title: <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/cesride/issues/116|#116 Audit constant-time evaluation where appropriate>

attachments.text:
*Rationale*

This PR aims to improve the security posture of `cesride` by removing mutability where possible, cleaning up unnecessary heap allocations/resizes/moves and zeroing sensitive buffers after use.

*Changes*

• adds `ZeroizeOnDrop` to `Signer` and `Salter`
• treats `Matter` conversions, since `Signer` and `Salter` both rely on the trait for encoding and decoding. this zeros buffers where they may contain sensitive information
• fixes instantiation of `Siger` from `Signer` to include `Verfer`.
• cleans up mutability where possible
• uses better copy methods so that the heap isn't littered with sensitive data

*Testing*

```
make clean preflight
```

attachments.text:
*Rationale*

When I tried to integrate I couldn't access inner macros. Also, the trait implementation of to_json() accomplished nothing other than to require the caller to make another import, so I moved it to the core implementation of `Value`.

*Changes*

• exports macros as serde-json does
• moves implementation of to_json()
• removes unnecessary imports
• changes convenience methods in signer to accept transferable param, as it cannot be inferred from the private material
• renames `data!` macro to `dat!` so that we can expose `cesride::data` as a module and not pollute the top level namespace with irrelevant structs that are required for the macro to work in other crates
• bumps version to 0.3.0 (changed Signer convenience api)

*Testing*

Integrated these changes on another computer with another library and copied them by hand. Tests passed! Then I used this remote branch and integrated again, and I seem to be able to access what I needed.

```
make fix clean preflight
```

attachments.text:
*Rationale*

This PR addresses <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/cesride/issues/129|#129>. I think it only really matters in `Matter`, since that's what Signer and Salter are based upon. If we think it makes sense we can change throughout the library to be consistent with preallocation, but we won't need the zeroization code so it won't look exactly the same anyway.

*Changes*

Uses zeroizing, preallocated vecs and `encode_slice()` to do minimal allocations and clear sensitive memory.

*Testing*

```
make fix clean preflight
```

attachments.text:
*Rationale*

Adds codes and implementation for `secp256r1` ecdsa signing and verification. This code will be required for anyone using Apple's existing secure enclaves and some HSMs.

*Changes*

• adds codes and implementation
• updates to a newer version of the secp256k1 crate

*Testing*

```
make clean fix preflight
```

*Notes*

I wrote this at night, unable to ask <https://github.com/pfeairheller|@pfeairheller> and with the expectation that it can merge before the Falcon prototype. If that goes first we'll need to change codes here.

Edit: We spoke and Falcon won't be merged first, so we can merge the codes here.

attachments.text:
*TL;DR*: Our dependencies should be audited to ensure they verify signatures in constant time.

Some paths are more sensitive that others with respect to constant time evaluation, but it's often the application that determines when this is required. In particular, we want to avoid verifications (and potentially other operations) that allow the adversary to glean knowledge about a particular operation due to differing response times. <https://cryptopals.com/sets/4/challenges/31|This> is a cryptopals exercise with an example of such an attack.

Basically, exiting algorithms and loops early may allow an attacker to understand how to forge signatures or otherwise defeat a cryptosystem. Constant time comparisons and algorithms combat these attacks.

We should evaluate our signing library dependencies to ensure they employ constant time algorithms.

attachments.text:
*Rationale*

Trying to make the magic happen. Currently a POC for Verfer but if we agree I can roll this out into the other primitives.

*Changes*

• Adds `uniffi` support
• Adds back convenience methods as wrappers around hidden constructor

*Testing*

`make clean preflight`

Also ran several tests in the python shell.

*Notes*

This is not perfect.

*Caveat: Codex Constants not exposed*

Couldn't figure out a way to express the Codex in the implementation of WebIDL 2 `uniffi` uses

*Caveat: `cesride` types require special treatment*

Working with our types requires special treatment to ensure thread safety. Refer here:  
<https://mozilla.github.io/uniffi-rs/udl/interfaces.html#concurrent-access|https://mozilla.github.io/uniffi-rs/udl/interfaces.html#concurrent-access>

I believe we need to wrap all our 'objects' in `Arc<>`. I found this out while working with Cigar. Try to expose the verfer() and set_verfer() functions and you'll see what happens. This seems like a very intrusive change to the library.

```
❯ make python-shell
   Compiling cesride v0.1.3 (/Users/jason/src/jasoncolburne/cesride)
    Finished release [optimized] target(s) in 2.32s
    Finished release [optimized] target(s) in 0.13s
     Running `target/release/cesride-bindgen generate src/cesride.udl --out-dir src/generated --language python`
Python 3.10.10 (main, Feb  8 2023, 05:40:53) [Clang 14.0.0 (clang-1400.0.29.202)] on darwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> from cesride import Diger
>>> dig = Diger(code="E", ser=b"some data")
>>> dig2 = Diger(code="F", ser=b"some data")
>>> dig3 = Diger(code="E", ser=b"other data")
>>> dig.verify(b"some data")
True
>>> dig.verify(b"other data")
False
>>> dig3.verify(b"other data")
True
>>> dig.compare_diger(b"some data", dig2)
True
>>> dig.compare_diger(b"some data", dig3)
False
>>> dig.compare_diger(b"other data", dig2)
False
>>> 
```

This option reflects parside implementation which return generic enum as result of the work (without particular groups definition).  
In this case we need to create a third crate combining parside and cerside and defining groups constructors + helpers. This crate will produce single library which will be consuming by other applications.

An alternative approach to: <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/parside/pull/2|#2>

attachments.text:
*Rationale*

The old version of OsRng based on a pinned version of `rand` has been bothering me, as has the length of time ed25519-dalek has gone without updates.

This bumps to the new `2.0.0-rc.2` version, fixing this problem and making other small improvements.

*Changes*

• uses `ed25519-dalek 2.0.0-rc.2`
• removes dependency `rand`
• drops ignore flag for rand in `cargo-outdated`
• checks for weak public keys (low order) on generation
• fixes `zeroize` features to include `derive` now that it is required for us
• makefile improvements
• adds WASM sanity build to CI

*Testing*

```
make clean fix preflight
```

Note: Coverage is dropping because I can't easily come up with a way to exercise the stock code that generates a weak public key (or maybe I can and I am lazy/ignorant - I haven't really dug into rust monkeypatching and I don't want to make this function use dependency injection).
attachments.title: <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/cesride/pull/144|#144 dalek 2.0.0-rc.2>
